member.name: T:SudokuStudio.Interop.IInitializeWithWindow
member.summary: Exposes a method through which a client can provide an owner window to a Windows Runtime (WinRT) object used in a desktop application.

remarks.para:
When to initialize:
Implement this interface if your object needs to be provided with an owner window, generally to display UI. Most third-party applications will not need to implement this interface.

When to use:
Use this interface if you will provide an owner window to a WinRT object in a desktop application. For more information about this scenario, see
Classes that use IInitializeWithWindow .

This interface is implemented by the following objects. Note that this is necessarily an incomplete list; refer to an individual object's documentation to determine whether that object implements this interface.

member.name: M:SudokuStudio.Interop.IInitializeWithWindow.Initialize(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Specifies an owner window to be used by a Windows Runtime (WinRT) object that is used in a desktop app.
member.param: The handle of the window to be used as the owner window.
member.remarks:
The method doesn't return anything, but the method returns an HResult value in the Win32 API. For more information, please visit
this link .

member.name: T:SudokuStudio.Interop.Monitor_DPI_Type
member.summary: Identifies the dots per inch (dpi) setting for a monitor.

remarks.para: All of these settings are affected by the PROCESS_DPI_AWARENESS of your application.
Source: MONITOR_DPI_TYPE enumeration (shellscalingapi.h).

summary.para: The effective DPI. This value should be used when determining the correct scale factor for scaling UI elements. This incorporates the scale factor set by the user for this specific display.
The angular DPI. This DPI ensures rendering at a compliant angular resolution on the screen. This does not include the scale factor set by the user for this specific display.

The raw DPI. This value is the linear DPI of the screen as measured on the screen itself. Use this value when you want to read the pixel density and not the recommended scaling setting. This does not include the scale factor set by the user for this specific display and is not guaranteed to be a supported DPI value.
